Qualifiers.scope: Classification of entry way structures based on height.
exclusions: Excludes structures classified as 'Vaulted entry way' (Panel C) or 'Combination porch & vaulted entry way' (Panel D).

Variables.name: Height
Variables.description: Height of the roofed entry way, measured from grade.

Constants.name: Height Threshold
Constants.description: The threshold height used to classify the entry way.

Conditions.description: To be classified as a 'Roofed entry way (not vaulted)', the structure's height must be less than 12 feet above grade.

Relationships.hierarchical: This rule defines one of the types of porches and entry ways illustrated in Figure 4.

cross_references.description: Specifies the mandatory procedure for 'how to measure height of porches & entry features'.

logical_dependencies: This classification is mutually exclusive with the classifications in Panel C and Panel D, which require a height greater than 12'.

ambiguous_language.reason: The text uses a height condition (< 12') as the sole determinant for a structure being 'not vaulted'. The term itself implies a lack of a specific architectural form (e.g., an arched ceiling), but the rule is based purely on dimension, not form. This could lead to ambiguity if a structure's form and height classification conflict.

Qualifiers.scope: Classification of entry way structures based on height.
exclusions: Excludes structures classified as 'Roofed entry way (not vaulted)' (Panel B).

Variables.name: Height
Variables.description: Height of the vaulted entry way, measured from grade.

Constants.name: Height Threshold
Constants.description: The threshold height used to classify the entry way.

Conditions.description: To be classified as a 'Vaulted entry way', the structure's height must be greater than 12 feet above grade.

Relationships.hierarchical: This rule defines one of the types of porches and entry ways illustrated in Figure 4.

cross_references.description: Specifies the mandatory procedure for 'how to measure height of porches & entry features'.

logical_dependencies: This classification is mutually exclusive with the classification in Panel B, which requires a height less than 12'.

ambiguous_language.reason: The text uses a height condition (> 12') as the sole determinant for a structure being 'vaulted'. The term itself implies a specific architectural form (e.g., an arched ceiling), which is not defined or required by the text. This could lead to ambiguity if a structure's form and height classification conflict (e.g., a flat-roofed entryway that is greater than 12' high).

Qualifiers.scope: Classification of combined porch and entry way structures based on height.
applicability: Applies to structures that are a combination of a porch and an entry way.

Variables.name: Height
Variables.description: Height of the combination structure, measured from grade.

Constants.name: Height Threshold
Constants.description: The threshold height used to classify the structure.

Conditions.description: To be classified as a 'Combination porch & vaulted entry way', the structure's height must be greater than 12 feet above grade.

Relationships.hierarchical: This rule defines one of the types of porches and entry ways illustrated in Figure 4.

cross_references.description: Specifies the mandatory procedure for 'how to measure height of porches & entry features'.

logical_dependencies: Shares the same height condition as 'Vaulted entry way' (Panel C).
This classification is mutually exclusive with the classification in Panel B, which requires a height less than 12'.

ambiguous_language.reason: The text uses a height condition (> 12') as the sole determinant for the 'vaulted' component of this structure type. The term 'vaulted' implies a specific architectural form, which is not defined. The distinction between this type and a 'Vaulted entry way' (Panel C) is also not clear from the text, other than the name 'Combination porch'.
